Identification.LongTitle: Public Ports and Public Port Facilities Regulations

Provision.Text: Her Excellency the Governor General in Council, on the recommendation of the Minister of Transport, pursuant to subsections 65(1), (4) and (6) of the Canada Marine Acta, hereby makes the annexed Public Ports and Public Port Facilities Regulations.

Section.Text: The ports set out in Schedule 1 are designated as public ports and have the limits set out in that Schedule.

Heading.TitleText: Repeal of Designation of Certain Public Ports

Subsection.Text: The designation under section 1 of a public port set out in Schedule 2 is repealed, effective on the day on which the entire public port facility at the port or the last part of it is transferred to a person or body by Her Majesty in Right of Canada as represented by the Minister of Transport.

The designation under section 1 of a public port set out in Schedule 3 is repealed effective on the day on which the bed of the navigable waters at the port that is owned by Her Majesty in Right of Canada, or the last part of it, or, if applicable, the day on which the entire public port facility at the port, or the last part of it, is transferred to a person or body by Her Majesty in Right of Canada as represented by the Minister of Transport, whichever is later.

Section.Text: The designation of Esquimalt as a public port under section 1 is repealed.
The designation of Nanoose Bay as a public port under section 1 is repealed.
The definitions in this section apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: Act means the Canada Marine Act. (Loi)
dangerous goods has the meaning assigned in section 2 of the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act, 1992. (marchandises dangereuses)
designated area means an area designated by a port official in respect of an activity set out in column 1 of Schedule 4. (endroit désigné)
fee means a fee fixed under subsection 67(1) of the Canada Marine Act or accepted by the Minister under section 68 of that Act. (droit)
floating structure means any type of floathome, houseboat, ship, work or other type of floating craft that is used for residential or commercial purposes. (construction flottante)
hot work means any work that uses flame or that can produce a source of ignition, such as heating, cutting or welding. (travail à chaud)

port official means, with respect to a public port or a public port facility, a representative of the Department of Transport, or a wharfinger or harbour master appointed under section 69 of the Act. (responsable de port)

Section.Text: This Part applies to public ports and public port facilities designated under section 65 of the Act and for which the Minister continues to have the management under subsection 72(8) of that Act.
This Part is binding on Her Majesty in right of Canada or a province.

Heading.TitleText: Safety and Order in Public Ports and Public Port Facilities

Section.Text: Unless otherwise authorized under these Regulations, no person shall, by act or omission, do anything or permit anything to be done in a public port or at a public port facility that has or is likely to have any of the following results:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to jeopardize the safety or health of persons in the public port or at the public port facility;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to interfere with navigation;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: to obstruct or threaten any part of the public port or the public port facility;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: to interfere with an authorized activity in the public port or at the public port facility;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: to divert the flow of a river or stream, cause or affect currents, cause silting or the accumulation of material or otherwise reduce the depth of the waters of the public port;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: to cause a nuisance;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: to cause damage to ships or other property;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: to adversely affect sediment, soil, air or water quality; or

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: to adversely affect public port or public port facility operations.

Section.Text: No person shall access any area of a public port facility unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person accesses the area to conduct legitimate business in the area;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person is authorized by a port official to access the area; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: access is not restricted by a sign or in some other way such as by a fence.

Section.Text: A port official may have signs posted or devices placed for the purpose of ensuring the safety of persons and property in a public port or at a public port facility, the environmental protection of the public port or the public port facility, or the management and development of the marine infrastructure and services in the public port or at the public port facility.

Subsection.Text: Every person in a public port or at a public port facility must comply with the instructions on signs posted and with devices placed under the authority of a port official unless the person is authorized by the port official to do otherwise.
No person shall remove, mark or deface any sign or device within a public port or at a public port facility.

Section.Text: No person shall operate a vehicle at a public port facility unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person holds all licences and permits required under the laws of the province and municipality in which the public port facility is situated to operate the vehicle in that province and municipality; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the vehicle is registered and equipped as required under the laws of the province and municipality in which the public port facility is situated.

Heading.TitleText: Compliance with Provincial and Municipal Laws

Section.Text: No person shall operate a vehicle at a public port facility except in accordance with the laws of the province and municipality in which the public port facility is situated.
Every person who operates a vehicle at a public port facility shall do so in a safe manner and at a speed that does not exceed the lowest of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 20 km/h;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the speed limit posted on signs at the public port facility; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the speed that is warranted by prevailing weather conditions or by the movement or storage of equipment, trains or goods.

Subsection.Text: A port official may have signs posted and devices placed at the public port facility respecting

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the safe operation of vehicles;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the parking or stopping of vehicles, including signs and devices restricting or prohibiting parking or stopping; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: weight and dimension restrictions of vehicles.

Subsection.Text: A person who operates a vehicle at a public port facility must comply

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: with the instructions on any sign posted or with any device placed by a port official and applicable to the person, vehicle or facility; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: with the traffic directions given by a port official.

Section.Text: A port official may have a vehicle moved or stored at the time at which the vehicle is found to be parked or stopped contrary to this section, if the vehicle is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: apparently abandoned;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: parked or stopped

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in a place or manner that creates a hazard or obstruction, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: at a time that is not within the posted parking or stopping hours; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: parked or stopped in an area

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: not posted as a parking or stopping area, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: posted as a no-parking or no-stopping area.

Subsection.Text: Unless otherwise authorized under these Regulations, a person who, in a public port or at a public port facility, drops, deposits, discharges or spills refuse, a substance that pollutes, cargo, ship’s gear or any other thing that interferes with navigation must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: immediately make every technically feasible and reasonable effort to remove it; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: notify a port official of the incident without delay and provide a description of what was dropped, deposited, discharged or spilled and its approximate location, and the efforts made by the person, if any, to remove it.

Subsection.Text: If the person does not remove the refuse, substance, cargo, ship’s gear or thing immediately, the port official may conduct the removal and, if the thing removed interfered with navigation, the removal may be done at the expense of the person.

Section.Text: Every person in a public port or at a public port facility must follow the fire protection and prevention measures established for the safety of persons and property in the public port or at the public port facility.
Every person who by act or omission causes a dangerous situation in a public port or at a public port facility must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: immediately take one of the following precautions:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: post the notices, deploy the lights and erect the fences, barricades or other devices that are necessary to prevent accidents and to protect persons and property, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: station a person at the site of the dangerous situation to warn persons of the danger;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: take appropriate measures to prevent injury to persons or damage to property; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: notify a port official without delay as to the nature of the dangerous situation and the precautions that have been taken and their location.

Section.Text: Despite any other provision of these Regulations, a person may, in a public port or at a public port facility, conduct an activity set out in column 1 of Schedule 4 without having a contract or lease with the Minister, or a licence granted by the Minister or authorization from a port official or without complying with the conditions of an authorization for the duration of an emergency situation if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the activity is required as a result of an emergency situation that jeopardizes the safety of persons or threatens to cause damage to property or the environment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person conducting the activity makes every effort to notify a port official of the activity and the emergency situation, if practicable; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the person conducting the activity submits a report to the port official without delay describing the activity and explaining why the situation was regarded as an emergency.

Section.Text: If a situation causes or is likely to cause death, bodily injury or any other emergency situation in a public port or at a public port facility, or damages or is likely to damage property or the environment, a person directly involved in the situation and, in the case of an activity conducted under a contract, lease, licence or authorization, the person authorized to conduct the activity, must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: notify a port official without delay of the emergency situation;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: submit a detailed report of the emergency situation to the port official as soon as possible after the situation ceases to exist; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: at the request of the port official, submit with the report to the port official a copy of each report of the emergency situation that the person makes to municipal, provincial and federal authorities.

Section.Text: A person who does anything in a public port or at a public port facility that results in an incident involving injury to a person, damage to the environment, material loss or damage, or an explosion, fire, accident, grounding, or stranding must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: notify a port official of the incident without delay; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: submit a detailed report of the incident to the port official as soon as possible after the incident occurs.

Subsection.Text: If, in a public port or at a public port facility, a person conducts an activity, other than an activity set out in Schedule 4, that is likely to have any of the results prohibited under section 14, a port official may instruct the person conducting the activity to cease the activity or to take the precautions reasonably necessary to mitigate or prevent the result.
The person must immediately comply with the instructions of the port official.

Section.Text: If a port official is the proponent of an activity that is set out in column 1 of Schedule 4 which is likely to have any of the results prohibited under section 14, the port official must take appropriate measures designed to mitigate or prevent the result, if technically feasible and reasonable, taking into account

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the safety of persons and property in the public port or at the public port facility;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the environmental protection of the public port or the public port facility; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the management and the development of the marine infrastructure and services in the public port or at the public port facility.

Heading.TitleText: Authorizations and Instructions for Activities in a Public Port and at a Public Port Facility
Activities under Contracts, Leases and Licences

Section.Text: A person may, in a public port or at a public port facility, conduct an activity set out in column 1 of Schedule 4 if authorized to do so in writing expressly or by necessary implication under a contract or lease entered into with, or a licence granted by, the Minister.

If, by entering into a contract or lease or granting a licence, the Minister authorizes an activity set out in column 1 of Schedule 4 that has or is likely to have any of the results prohibited under section 14, the Minister may stipulate as a condition of the contract, lease or licence that the person with whom the contract or lease is made or to whom the licence is granted must take measures designed to mitigate or prevent the result, if technically feasible and reasonable.

Heading.TitleText: Authorizations by Posted Signs or Forms

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), a port official may, by such means as posted signs, posted notices, maps or forms, give an authorization under this section to conduct, in a public port or at a public port facility, an activity set out in column 1 of Schedule 4 if an “X” is set out in column 2.

If the conduct of the activity is not likely to have a result prohibited under section 14, the port official may give the authorization without conditions, as long as the authorization is posted in a prominent place clearly visible to persons wanting to conduct the activity.
If the conduct of the activity is likely to have a result prohibited under section 14, the port official may give the authorization for the activity only if the port official

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: establishes conditions designed to mitigate or prevent the result; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: communicates the conditions by

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: posting them in a prominent place clearly visible to persons wanting to conduct the activity, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: setting them out on forms that are readily available to persons wanting to conduct the activity.

Subsection.Text: No person shall conduct an activity set out in column 1 of Schedule 4 if an “X” is set out in column 2 unless the person complies with the conditions, if any, for conducting the activity that are posted or set out on forms and pays the applicable fee, if any.
If a condition for conducting the activity is to complete a checklist, the person conducting the activity must keep the checklist readily available for inspection.
A port official may give an authorization under this section to a person to conduct, in a public port or at a public port facility, an activity set out in column 1 of Schedule 4 if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an “X” is set out in column 3; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an “X” is set out in column 2 and the person or any person who would be covered by the authorization is unable to comply with the conditions posted or set out on forms for the conduct of the activity under section 33.

Subsection.Text: On receipt of a request for an authorization, along with payment of the applicable fee, if any, and the information required under subsection 36(2), the port official must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: give their authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the results of the conduct of the activity are uncertain or if the conduct of the activity is likely to have any of the results prohibited under section 14,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: refuse to give their authorization, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: give their authorization subject to conditions designed to mitigate or prevent the results; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the port official required that the person obtain insurance coverage, performance security or damage security in respect of the conduct of the activity and none is obtained or that which is obtained is inadequate, refuse to give their authorization.

Subsection.Text: No person shall, in a public port or at a public port facility, conduct an activity set out in column 1 of Schedule 4 if an “X” is set out in column 3 unless the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: obtains an authorization under section 35 or is covered by an authorization given to a partnership, an association or a body corporate under that section; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: complies with the conditions, if any, of the authorization.

Subsection.Text: A person that seeks an authorization from a port official to conduct an activity in a public port or at a public port facility must provide to the port official

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the applicable fee, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: information relevant to the proposed activity and required by the port official to assess the likelihood of the occurrence of any of the results prohibited under section 14;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if requested by the port official, proof that the applicant has an insurance policy that provides adequate coverage for the activity, names Her Majesty in right of Canada as an additional insured and provides for the insurer to notify the port official in the event that the policy is amended or cancelled; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: if required by the port official, performance security and damage security in respect of the conduct of the activity.

Section.Text: A port official may cancel an authorization given under section 35 or change the conditions to which an authorization is subject if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the conduct of the activity has a result prohibited under section 14 or, as a result of a change in circumstances, becomes likely to have such a result;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the authorization was based on incorrect or misleading information; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the person to whom the authorization is given or any person covered by the authorization does not comply with a condition of the authorization.

Subsection.Text: If an authorization given under section 35 is cancelled, the port official must give notice of the cancellation to the person to whom the authorization was given.
The cancellation is effective at the earliest of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the end of the fifth business day after the notice of cancellation is sent by registered mail to the address provided in the application for the authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: two hours after a facsimile or electronic transmission of the notice of cancellation is sent to the address provided in the application for the authorization; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: immediately on service of the notice of cancellation at the address provided in the application for the authorization.

Heading.TitleText: Instructions to Cease, Remove, Return and Restore

Subsection.Text: A port official may instruct a person to take any of the actions referred to in subsection (2) if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person conducts an activity for which an authorization is required under section 35 without first obtaining the authorization or without being covered by one;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person, or any person covered by the authorization, fails to comply with a condition of the authorization;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the authorization to conduct the activity is cancelled under section 37; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an activity for which no authorization is required under these Regulations, the conduct of the activity has a result prohibited under section 14.

Subsection.Text: The actions are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to cease the activity or comply with the conditions for conducting the activity; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the person is instructed to cease the activity,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: to remove anything brought into the public port or to the public port facility in connection with the activity,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: to return to the public port or the public port facility anything that was removed from it in connection with the activity, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: to restore the property affected by the activity to its former state.

Subsection.Text: The person must comply immediately with the instructions of the port official.
If the person fails to remove the thing or to restore the property immediately, the port official may conduct the removal or restoration and may store the thing.
If the thing removed or stored by the port official interfered with navigation, the removal and, if applicable, the storage may be done at the expense of the person.

Heading.TitleText: Information in Respect of Ships and Cargoes

Subsection.Text: This section applies in respect of ships for which fees are fixed under subsection 67(1) of the Act or accepted under section 68 of that Act.

At least 24 hours before a ship enters a public port or arrives at a public port facility, the owner or the person in charge of the ship must provide the following information to a port official if the information has not already been provided for the purpose of obtaining permission to access the public port or public port facility:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the ship, its port of registry and its identification number as it appears in the Lloyd’s Register of Shipping or on the ship’s certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the owner, the master and the agent of the ship;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the gross tonnage of the ship and its overall length;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the port from which and the date on which the ship began its voyage;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the estimated time of arrival of the ship in the public port or at the public port facility;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the estimated draught of the ship on arrival in the public port or at the public port facility and on departure;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the description, quantity and tonnage of dangerous goods that are in transit on the ship or that will be loaded, unloaded or transferred in the public port or at the public port facility, in the form provided by the port official;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the description, quantity and tonnage of goods to be loaded, unloaded or transferred in the public port or at the public port facility;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the number of passengers in transit on the ship, embarking on the ship or disembarking from the ship;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: if the ship is not engaged in cargo or passenger operations, the purpose of the ship’s visit to the public port;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the last port of call of the ship and its next intended port of call; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: any other information requested by the port official and relevant to assessing the likelihood of the occurrence of any of the results prohibited under section 14 or to the management of the marine infrastructure and services of the public port or the public port facility.

Subsection.Text: The owner or the person in charge of the ship must provide the port official with the description, quantity and tonnage of the cargo loaded, unloaded or transferred at each berth or anchorage within 24 hours after the loading, unloading or transferral, but before the ship’s departure.
The information must be provided by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: delivering it by hand in the form of a certificate signed by the owner or person in charge of the ship; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: sending it by facsimile or electronic transmission.

Subsection.Text: If a ship is waiting for another ship to load, unload or transfer cargo to get a berth or anchorage, the owner or the person in charge of the other ship must ensure that, regardless of whether working around the clock is necessary or overtime charges are incurred,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the loading, unloading or transfer operations are conducted with dispatch; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the cargo is moved with dispatch from the immediate vicinity of the berth or anchorage to enable the waiting ship to load, unload or transfer its cargo.

Subsection.Text: If the loading, unloading or transfer operations of the ship, or the movement of its cargo, are not conducted with dispatch, a port official may instruct the owner or the person in charge of the ship

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to move the ship from the berth or anchorage to allow the waiting ship to berth or to anchor and begin its loading, unloading or transfer operations; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to move the cargo from the immediate vicinity of the berth or anchorage.

Subsection.Text: If, to allow a waiting ship to berth or to anchor promptly, the loading, unloading or transfer operations of a ship, or the movement of its cargo, are conducted around the clock or the ship or cargo is moved on the instructions of the port official, the owner or person in charge of the waiting ship must ensure that, regardless of whether working around the clock is necessary or overtime charges are incurred,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the loading, unloading or transfer operations of the waiting ship are conducted with dispatch; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the cargo of the waiting ship is moved with dispatch from the immediate vicinity of the berth or anchorage.

Subsection.Text: The owner or the person in charge of a ship berthed, moored or anchored in a public port or at a public port facility must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a port official is kept informed of the location and telephone number of a person who can take command of the ship immediately at the request of the port official if it is necessary to move it for the safety of persons or property in the public port or at the public port facility or the management of the port or facility; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsection (2), the ship is kept in a state of readiness so that it can be moved quickly.

Subsection.Text: Paragraph (1)(b) does not apply to a ship in respect of which an authorization to lay-up in the public port or at the public port facility has been obtained.

For purposes of management, control and use of a public port, a port official may order the removal, within a reasonable time fixed by the port official, of any ship from an area to another area of the public port or the alteration of its position if that ship interferes with navigation.

If the person in charge of the ship fails to remove the ship or alter its position within the reasonable time, the port official may have the ship removed or its position altered at the expense of the person.

Section.Text: The owner or the person in charge of a ship that is berthed, moored or anchored in a public port or at a public port facility must ensure that the ship is fitted with arrangements suitable for attaching a towing line so that the ship can be towed from its berth, mooring or anchorage if moving the ship is necessary for the safety of persons or property within the public port or at the public port facility.

All the navigable waters, including any foreshore, of Plaisance Bay and Leslie Cove within the following described boundaries:
